Package xyz.acygn.mokapot

A library for transparently making Java programs distributed.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    CommunicationAddress
    Information allowing a particular VM involved in a distributed computation to be contacted.
    Copiable
    A marker interface specifying that an object can be safely replaced with a copy/clone without changing the semantics of the program.
    CopiableRunnable
    A Runnable that's safe to copy and serialisable.
    CopiableSupplier<T>
    A Supplier that's safe to copy and serialisable.
    DebugMonitor
    A functional interface for classes that monitor the messages sent to or from a distributed communicator.
    LongReference
    Common interface for all long references.
    NonCopiable
    A marker interface warning that a given class should not be copied to another system, even if doing so appears to be semantically safe.
    ProxyOrWrapper<T>
    An interface that marks a class as acting like a proxy or wrapper for another specific class.
    ProxyOrWrapper.Namespacer
    The type of a dummy parameter used to prevent naming clashes between ProxyOrWrapper#getReferentClass() and methods of other classes that randomly happen to be named "getReferentClass".
    Standin<T>
    A standin is a class that's used in place of another class, to transparently add functionality.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    ArrayKnowledge<T>
    Knowledge about array classes.
    Authorisation
    A class that can only be created via the internals of this library.
    ClassKnowledge<T>
    Information used in marshalling a given class.
    CopiableKnowledge<T>
    Knowledge about how to make a copy of objects of a given class.
    DistributedCommunicator
    An object that handles communication to and from remote systems.
    DistributedServer
    The main class of this application.
    DistributionUtils
    Utility class to namespace static methods that handle marshalling, unmarshalling, and long references.
    ForwardingStandinStorage<T>
    A standin storage method that forwards method invocations to another object (perhaps on another virtual machine).
    IndirectStandin<T>
    Abstract implementation of composition-based standins.
    InterfaceKnowledge<T>
    As much knowledge as we can determine about classes that extend a given interface.
    LambdaKnowledge<T>
    Knowledge about how to make a copy of an object belonging to a lambda class (that is, a lambda or method reference).
    LengthIndependent
    Redefinitions of Java's primitive operations to treat long references and short references the same way.
    LoopbackCommunicationAddress
    A TCPCommunicationAddress designed for running a "distributed" computation entirely on a single machine, using TCP connections on the loopback interface.
    MethodMessage
    A message which tells the recipient system to run a specified method.
    NonCopiableKnowledge<T>
    Knowledge about a class that allows us to create long references to it.
    SiteLocalCommunicationAddress
    A TCPCommunicationAddress designed for situations in which the communication takes place over a site-local network, using site-local addresses.
    StandinStorage<T>
    The method via which a standin currently accesses its storage.
    StaticInternetCommunicationAddress
    A TCPCommunicationAddress designed for situations in which the communication takes place over the public Internet, and machines are contacted via connecting to a predetermined public IP.
    TCPCommunicationAddress
    An implementation of a communication address that assumes that each system involved in the distributed communication has an IP address via which all other machines can contact them on a specified port.
    TrivialStandinStorage<T>
    Storage for a standin that causes it to act like a regular, local Java object.
    UnmarshallableKnowledge<T>
    A class representing knowledge about classes that cannot be marshalled via any known method.
    UnreliablyCopiableKnowledge<T>
    Knowledge about how to attempt to make a copy of objects of a given class.
  • Error Summary 
    Error Description
    DistributedError
    An Error thrown as a response to an exception that occurred as a result of attempting distributed communications.

Package xyz.acygn.mokapot Description

A library for transparently making Java programs distributed.

This library handles all the background operations needed to allow a program to run on more than one machine, aiming to keep the behaviour of the program as similar as possible to if it were running on only a single machine. The main difference to running without this library is that an object that exists on one machine can be stored (by reference) in a variable or field that exists on another machine. The references are completely transparent, in the sense that calling a methods on a reference will cause that method to run on that object.

In the most general case, a method on an object will always run on the same machine as the object itself. However, this is an implementation detail (due to the fact that not all objects can sensibly be moved between machines), and in cases where it's known that running the method on a copy of the object would be safe, the method may well run in the same place it's invoked (using a deep or shallow copy of the object to run it on, whichever would behave the same way as a call on the object itself). This mechanism can be enhanced via use of the Copiable interface, which allows the user to specify classes which are safe to copy this way (even if they might appear to be unsafe to copy to a computer).

To use this library, create, configure and start a DistributedCommunicator; that will allow distributed programs to run on the current Java virtual machine. If you only want to allow programs from elsewhere to run on this machine (rather than starting a program on your own), you can use DistributedServer (a command-line program that simply wraps DistributedCommunicator) for the purpose. Typically, a distributed computation will be started on one computer (that creates a DistributedCommunicator of its own), and allowed to continue onto other computers that are just running a DistributedServer. Note that this mechanism is subject to change (because the current arrangement is hard to secure).

Even with multiple machines involved, the entire program will run on a single machine unless some of the computation is moved to another machine. This can be done using DistributedCommunicator#runRemotely. For optimum performance, try to avoid the moved parts of the communication referencing non-Copiable (or effectively copiable, e.g. due to being immutable) objects that exist on the original machine. Hopefully, this process will some day be automated, but for the time being you will need to manually specify what to run where.

See Also:
DistributedServer, DistributedCommunicator, DistributedCommunicator.runRemotely( xyz.acygn.mokapot.CopiableSupplier, xyz.acygn.mokapot.CommunicationAddress), Copiable
